PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Carcinoma In Situ Absent Ductal Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Carcinoma In Situ Absent Ductal Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:Related to, or having the quality of, a duct.:Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.:A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.
Related to, or having the quality of, a duct.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Carcinoma In Situ Present Common Bile Duct Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Carcinoma In Situ Present Common Bile Duct Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:Bile ducts are passageways that carry bile. Two major bile ducts come together into a "trunk"-the common bile duct which empties into the upper part of the small intestine (the part next to the stomach).:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.:A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Bile ducts are passageways that carry bile. Two major bile ducts come together into a "trunk"-the common bile duct which empties into the upper part of the small intestine (the part next to the stomach).

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Carcinoma In Situ Present Pancreatic Parenchyma Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Carcinoma In Situ Present Pancreatic Parenchyma Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:The tissue that constitutes the essential part of an organ as contrasted with e.g., connective tissue and blood vessels.:Of or pertaining to the pancreas.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.:A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.
Of or pertaining to the pancreas.
The tissue that constitutes the essential part of an organ as contrasted with e.g., connective tissue and blood vessels.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
